<s> <user> <unka@> , just so you're aware , when i was messing with how to structure the <unka'> <unka_> implementations , i noticed <unka-> numerical differences in some little toy test <unka> between a couple of different implementations that <unka> only in where or how i was <unka> , say sample weight and bootstrap weights . </s>
<s> <user> i'd expect that the change in <unk##> will definitely change the way small floating point differences are evaluated . this obviously has a big effect in trees as magnitude does n't matter , just <unka> improvement ... so the outputs using <unka_> between implementations will likely be different for <unka> , probably trees . not that this really matters as they are both entering @ 0.16 </s>
<s> <user> long story short , i think <unka> and linear models could potentially change a little bit with <unk##> , though not as bad as trees i 'm guessing . i 'm not sure what " promise " is made to users about <unka> between <unka-> versions ... </s>

<s> <user> <unka-> is not a community of mapreduce users so i doubt you will get good feedback on here . you might rather ask on a discussion forum with spark or <unka> users . i am not sure that using the hadoop <unka> api is a good thing for <unka> machine learning anyway . it 's probably better to build upon higher level parallel construct like <unka> or the spark api in general . </s>
<s> <user> the thing is that i have a huge dataset and i do n't want to use <unka-> since that means i have to guess the optimal number of clusters each time </s>
<s> <user> also if you still want to ask questions about the paper on a discussion forum , you should ask specific questions , otherwise you probably wo n't get any interesting answer . </s>
<s> <user> i have no idea where to start </s>
<s> <user> how do i adapt the existing algorithm to be parallel ? </s>
<s> <user> use <unka> <unka> on a subset with <unk#a(=_> ) and <unk#a(=_> ) </s>
<s> <user> i 'm not much of an ml guy but i 'm trying to learn </s>
<s> <user> if you are trying to learn , start with smaller <unka> ( e.g . a random subset ) where algo run fast . to learn stuff you will have to fail many times to learn from your mistakes . if each failures take days of cluster programming and execution you will learn slowly :) by working on a subset that fits in memory on your laptop you will learn much faster . </s>
<s> <user> but working on a subset of the data is meaningless </s>

<s> <user> URL/http:/ <unka./> : even <unka> is moving away from mapreduce : 25 april 2014 - goodbye mapreduce the <unka> community decided to move its codebase onto modern data processing systems that offer a <unka> programming model and more efficient execution than hadoop mapreduce . <unka> will therefore reject new mapreduce algorithm implementations from now on . we will however keep our widely used mapreduce algorithms in the codebase and maintain them . we are building our future implementations on top of a dsl for linear <unka> operations which has been developed over the last months . programs written in this dsl are automatically optimized and executed in parallel on apache spark . furthermore , there is an experimental contribution undergoing which aims to integrate the h20 platform into <unka> . </s>

<s> <user> its just a <unka> , except that the final result is expressed as a non-linear equation . </s>

<s> <user> basic idea is to take an initial sample of random equations and apply <unka> operations such as <unka> , reproduction , etc to the <unka> individuals in a population . the equations are expressed like lisp trees ... well im just using python lists , but similar structure </s>

<s> <user> > <unka@> thats great !! btw why does n't <unka> do the doc tests ? only travis does it ? ( not that it should be of any concern ) because on windows some type <unka`> are slightly different ( i think for int vs long on python 2 iirc ) and some <unka> would have a different representation . porting the <unka> to be cross-platform would be painful . <unka> should be considered a way to check that the documentation is up to date with the code . so if it passes on one platform , we know that the doc is up to date . for unit tests on the other hand we want to test on all the supported platforms to make sure that the code is fully cross-platform . </s>

<s> <user> to answer , i do n't see why <unka> would be better or worse than anything else . the gist of the problem is the estimation of the score . if you use <unka> instead of lolo you will <unka> . </s>
<s> <user> the idea of validation is to estimate how your model would do in a realistic setting . if your observations are grouped and they arrive in groups , it 's not realistic to assume that you can be able to train on some samples from the same groups that you will run it on . </s>
<s> <user> i guess <unka> is likely to <unka> . but it 's not a question of <unka> k . it 's one of methodology </s>
<s> <user> think of search queries . if real life users would look for exactly the same queries you have in your training set , <unk#a> can return perfect results . but that 's not a realistic of interesting case . </s>
<s> <user> if you " <unka> " your evaluation with this kind of data you can think your system <unka> much better than it really does . </s>
<s> <user> because the model can implicitly learn to recognize the <unka> group label , and then get some of the test points predicted really well </s>
<s> <user> i hope this makes sense . i gtg </s>

<s> <user> <unk#a@> regarding the dataset : you can take the <unka> dataset and invent arbitrary group ids ( as you already have ), but generate a new <unka`> based on a formula you come up with ( a function of one or two features and also of the <unka_> ) </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> oh ... reasons why i admire <unka> learn ... ok ... a ) i find the documentation very impressive in its effort to be genuinely useful and usable by <unka-> . this is not such a common thing to see . b ) i love that developers who say " how about we include feature x from paper y " are told " sure . find us a public data set where this method does better than something we already have and give us code that we can test on it ." it 's a great attitude . c ) i love that everything is being continually improved . things that work , e.g . decision trees , random <unka> are not just left as " good enough " but are being made better all the time </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> there is no feature for doing the top k <unka-> in <unka-> . clearly you could easily do that with some custom code . btw , is the data public ? a very good approach when having that many categories might be target frequency encoding . there was a discussion about that on the mailing list , and maybe there is a pr . look at a talk by owen <unka> for an explanation </s>
<s> <user> basically you represent each category using <unka_> many floats that encode the class distribution for this category </s>

<s> <user> <unk##> ready for merge . minor changes to documentation . straightforward . </s>
<s> <user> 200+ <unka> is not a hard and fast rule ... if the suggestion is for an <unka/> that is not fundamentally different from a well established algorithm and gives a very significant performance improvement , it would be worthwhile to implement the same ... basically , the idea is that we do n't want code that might rot over time without a substantial userbase or maintainers to support or both ... essentially u can compress that rule to this -- <unka(`> a lot of people who already use <unka> benefit from this ?) || ( will it help bring *a lot* of new people to <unka> ?, if its a completely new feature )) && ( does it fit well within our api ?) && !( will it make life tougher for the existing <unka)`> ;) </s>

<s> <user> i mean , kernels extend far past just <unka> of data . there are kernels to compare tree based structures , or graphs , to each other . </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> that 's very interesting ... although i am a little surprised by the trees being slow </s>
<s> <user> why ? </s>
<s> <user> doing an inner product is super fast , compared to <unka> n binary trees . </s>
<s> <user> i 'm not trying to <unka> either rf or deep learning , which are super powerful , but <unka> <unka> are a small subset of ml problems out there . </s>

<s> <user> i am wondering if i have misunderstood URL/https:/ URL/github.com/ <unk#a#-/> . is the question if <unka(> ) is fast in c ? </s>
<s> <user> the thing is nan in ieee std has two possible representations ( <unka> , which is the quiet nan where we explicitly specify values to be nan and <unka> where nan is a signal nan and is a ( possibly unexpected ) result of numeric computation , like in <unka> 's comment ... ) so <unka> was wondering if that would make <unka_`> computation in <unka/> less efficient ... your <unka> point was correct in that <unka> does use a consistent nan representation for both <unka/> ( atleast that is what i understood from that link ), whereas numpy does n't have one ... i think it wo n't really affect the speed ... but i am not sure ... i am currently working on benchmarking that ... </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> interesting ! in c you really just have to do <unka!=> which is true iff x = nan . this is exactly one comparison </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> i also looked at the assembly that you get from <unka(> ) from gcc which is quite interesting too :) </s>
<s> <user> could you share ? </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> sure .. using math.h , <unka(> ) compiles to jmp <unka_> . however return x ! = x compiles to xor eax , eax <unka> <unk#a> , <unk#a> setp al ret </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> however it turns out gcc had a performance bug and bleeding edge <unka(> ) compiles to something closer to the latter assembly .. does this make sense ? </s>
<s> <user> i am not sure if the latter <unka!=> will work in all compilers ... but that is the most effective way to check for nan afaik ... in general , iirc <unka`> will handle the <unka(> ) effectively ( i.e not distinguish between multiple nan representations ) </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> i think you are right <unk#a> <unka> the use of a macro for this . <unka!=> certainly works in gcc however and i assume all sensible compilers </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> if you are interesting .. this was the gcc performance bug URL/https:/ <unka./> <unk#a./=?_> . fixed on <unk#-> </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> i looked it up .. it seems any <unk#a> compliant c compiler is guaranteed to do <unka!=> correctly that is <unka!=> iff x is nan </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> it is specified in URL/http:/ <unka-./> <unk#a#&,-./=> section <unk#a.> relational operators </s>
<s> <user> but in any case ... <unka(> ) is much easier to read and gcc will compile it properly soon :) ( i do n't really understand the math.h versus <unka.> point in any case ) </s>

<s> <user> whats the recommended way to recompile a single <unka.> file after i modify it ? </s>
<s> <user> you just do the <unka`> setup.py <unka_`> or <unka`> setup.py <unka_> -i` ( for inplace building ) again . it generates c and recompiles for the changed <unka> sources only . </s>
<s> <user> if you just want to compile , you could do <unka`> <unka.`> . but you probably want to build in place again for it all to work together . </s>

<s> <user> i have lots of feature vectors with numerical . the numerical values are a little odd however . say the numbers are in the range <unk#-> the 69 and 123 might have a particular meaning but i do n't get to know which ones those are in advance . a random forest works really well for <unka> as it magically picks out those special values . so that part is great </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> - your numerical variables are actually <unka> . or they're a mix of <unka> and continuous variables , and your data is n't in a tidy format . either way , there are literally multiple whole <unka> on selecting a good clustering method . </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> i guess that also helps devs understand which part of their code is so unintuitive to newbies . i mean that 's like a window , although nasty one , into the users mind . " okay this is a common concern with everyone . let 's document this as a faq ." </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> they are exactly a mix of <unka> and numerical i suppose . they are all integer <unka> so not exactly continuous . </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@> i appreciate your ability to look on the bright side , but after being in that forum for a while ... </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> i think you need to first separate out the 69 and 123 into 2 separate features . and later try out different clustering algorithms on it ? </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> oh i did some research but did n't find anything that covered this situation where a particular feature is part <unka> and part numerical but you do n't know in advance which parts are which </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> if you have a single variable that 's a combination of <unka> and continuous variables , then your data is n't in a tidy format , and unless you did that on purpose because you're <unka-> , you are n't going to be able to get results out of that . </s>
<s> <user> the reson you're not finding anything covering it , is that what you need to do is break each variable up to separate <unka> and numerical parts . that is part of the task of cleaning your data which is part of every machine learning project . </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> ok i do . the point is that using a random forest as a <unka> works really well so i somehow feel i should be able to use this fact </s>

<s> <user> okay then use the rf . that would be possible i think ! </s>
<s> <user> these are byte counts in some network traffic . some individual byte counts indicate particular behaviour </s>
<s> <user> but the others are just how large the data transfer happens to be </s>
<s> <user> then what you want to do is create additional variables for whether the byte count matches particular known behaviors </s>
<s> <user> i feel there should be an entirely <unka> way . for example URL/https:/ <unka./> <unka./> ? </s>

<s> <user> hi guys i m having a doubt if i train a <unka> and pickle it . how to make it relearn everytime when i introduce a new test example . is it like everytime i want to predict something i need to <unka> with updated training set or will the updating can happen on the go .? </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> in my opinion <unka> with every new test example is a bad idea , mainly because it will change the accuracy characteristics of your model over time . not necessarily always towards the better . some <unka> methods support very natural " updating " . otherwise you can look into " <unka> learning " which may be better suited to your task if you need to learn " online " . </s>
<s> <user> it may also be a good idea to keep the new examples in a special " out of sample " test set , and evaluate ongoing accuracy on that test set . </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> thank you :) </s>

<s> <user> hey folks , id like to understand the implementation of the random <unka> . is there a specific reason why <unka(_> ) is a function and not a method ? </s>
<s> <user> because it is a helper which is called inside the <unka`> method . </s>
<s> <user> the <unka_`> param that you set at the initialization of <unka`> controls the number of processes used by <unka`> ... </s>
<s> <user> the <unka`> uses <unka`> 's <unka`> to run the <unka_`> helper in batches to build <unka_`> trees at a time . </s>

<s> <user> hey everyone , i have a <unka_> for you ! </s>
<s> <user> <unk`> def <unka(_> ): <unconvertable > """ turns a <unka> <unka(> ) - -> <unka(> ) <unconvertable > <unconvertable > pipeline into single weights and bias . """ <unconvertable > <unconvertable > assert <unka(._> )) == { <unka'> , <unka'> } <unconvertable > <unconvertable > <unka> = <unka'.[_> ] <unconvertable > <unconvertable > sc = <unka'.[_> ] <unconvertable > <unconvertable > w = ( <unka._> <unka._> ) <unconvertable > <unconvertable > b = <unka._> - ( <unka._> <unka()._> ) <unconvertable > <unconvertable > return ( w , b ) <unk`> </s>
<s> <user> for those doing <unka> regression , this turns a <unka> + <unka> pipeline into a single <unka+> matrix </s>
<s> <user> you use it like this : <unk`> x = <unk#a(.> , 512 ) <unka,> = <unka(_> ) assert <unka(.> <unka(._> ), <unka(.> ) + b ) <unka%> <unka(._> ) <unk#=> > 10 loops , best of 3 : 122 ms per loop <unka%> <unka(.> ) + b <unk#=> > the slowest run took <unk#.> times longer than the fastest . this could mean that an intermediate result is being cached . <unk#=> > 1000 loops , best of 3 : 265 us per loop <unk`> </s>
<s> <user> the speedup is significant </s>
<s> <user> the real funny part is that the resulting calculation runs only on a single core , even though it 's hundreds of times faster than <unka> vanilla pipeline </s>
<s> <user> now , i have 1800 of these <unka> to run . it 's much faster to do a ( <unk#,> ) * ( 512 , n ) matrix operation than to call 1800 pipelines in sequence </s>
<s> <user> hmm , thats pretty interesting </s>
<s> <user> this makes me wonder if <unka> could n't benefit from some pipeline optimization tricks ? i know i'd love like a <unka`> class </s>
<s> <user> but of course there could be other possible ways to <unka-> other combinations of linear <unka> ( e.g . <unka> and random <unka> are the same thing ) </s>

<s> <user> and will i able to understand regression funtion after reading linear <unka> ? </s>
<s> <user> i do n't have any particular recommendation in mind but if you ask that question to google you will probably get answers </s>
<s> <user> regression is a stats machine learning concept , not a linear algebra concept . but generally it is presented in terms of vector space with a <unka> metric so you need to know about vector spaces and <unka> and distances first </s>
<s> <user> which math course would you recommend for understanding regression ( vector .. etc ) </s>
<s> <user> to apply ml you do n't necessarily need to understand the underlying math in details though . it 's good to start with a bit of ml practice ( e.g . <unka> tutorials ) then learn a bit about the underlying maths and then iterate </s>
<s> <user> i am working with <unka> flow api </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> so <unka-> <unka> means , that if i use e.g . <unk#a-> cross validation , there 's 10 <unka-> <unka> , i.e . dataset is split into 10 and then the model is trained on 9 of those and one is used for testing . and this is repeated until every one of those 10 is used as testing . right ? </s>
<s> <user> yes </s>
<s> <user> ok , so that part i understood </s>
<s> <user> what is the training score then ? </s>
<s> <user> scores are computed for each of the 10 iterations </s>
<s> <user> and each iteration has a 9 <unka> that the model is trained on and one that it is tested on </s>
<s> <user> the training score is the score on the training set , i.e . the 9 <unka> </s>
<s> <user> so , is the model is evaluated on those 9 <unka> too , at same iteration ? </s>
<s> <user> yes . training score meaning the data it was trained on </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> <unk#a> is also fine but <unk#a> feels like standard . you can claim your accuracy better . lets dive in : if you have <unk#a=> . that is 5 <unka> what you do is to divide the data set into 5 sets of equal length say <unk#a,> ..... s5 . now you take s1 as test s2 ... s5 as training set and check accuracy . each of the set gets a chance to become a test <unka.> you would get 5 <unka-> average it and get the mean accuracy . usage : sometimes using a particular split you can get better results but in real world you model does n't performs good . so try some splits and get the average it helps you see the truth . </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> there is some randomness in the decision tree . for instance a subset of feature can be taken at each note with a <unka> . having this in mind the <unka_> allows to have this part deterministic as well </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> - thank you very much . thats helpful and i want to add that the book i was following written by <unka@> had a sentence saying " we fix the <unka_> in the tree , which is used for <unka> internally " . i was wondering about the mechanism of tie breaking thing . how is the tie breaking thing happens internally ? </s>

<s> <user> hey guys , i am planning to build a ml and <unka> modelling <unka> in python . would like to know if anybody is interested to start the project with me ? </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> at each node , a random set of feature will be used to find a best split . if there two features leading to a split with the same <unka> improvement , you get a tie . therefore , the first feature which was randomly picked up will be selected . </s>
<s> <user> if you try multiple times , you will select one feature or the other which will lead to different trees architectures . therefore , <unka_> allows you to pick up always the same feature in case of a tie . </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> how will it be different from current existing libraries ? </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> would be much focused on <unka> uncertainty . </s>
<s> <user> have you looked into <unk#a> and <unka> , and the libraries built on top of those ? </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> yeah . i find them a bit compound and complex to use . would be nice to have something with the same apis design as <unka> </s>
<s> <user> you should probably reach out in those communities then , if you 'll be building on top of it . i think that learning <unka> models like that is much more niche than classical machine learning . </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> thank you very much <unka.> appreciate your help . great explanation there </s>

<s> <user> use the <unka_`> where you have the <unka> <unka-> classes </s>
<s> <user> long story short , you can write your code as </s>
<s> <user> <unka`> from <unka._> import <unka> from <unka._> <unka_> from <unka.> import <unka> <unka> = <unka'(=> ) <unka(_> , x , y )) <unk`> </s>
<s> <user> then it seems that you try to actually find the best <unka`> parameter probably . to do that you should use the [ <unka(-./:]_`> ) class . </s>
<s> <user> <unka`> from <unka> import svm , <unka> from <unka._> import <unka> parameters = { 'c' : [ 1 , 10 , 100 , 1000 <unk]}> <unka> = <unka'(.=> ) <unka> = <unka(> , parameters ) <unka(.> , y ) <unk`> </s>
<s> <user> it will search and select the best <unka`> parameter </s>

<s> <user> hi all , i want to revisit the question regarding how to interpret the output of <unka_`> something meaningful . with the output from <unka_`> , how can i determine if a prediction is trust worthy or not , given some threshold <unka`> ? </s>
<s> <user> there is no generic method , it depends on your <unka> and the kind of <unka> reduction used by the underlying model ( e.g . one vs one for <unka> , one vs all for most other models such as <unka> ). </s>
<s> <user> you might also have <unka> prediction errors : some regions of your feature space might lead to a higher error rate and this <unka> might not be part of the model assumptions ( or maybe cannot be handled properly by the model capacity ). </s>
<s> <user> which model family are you interested in ? one interesting thing to consider is using a calibrated <unka> ( especially for binary <unka> ): URL/http:/ <unka-./> <unka./> this way you can better interpret the output of <unka._`> . this wo n't solve any <unka> issues though . </s>
<s> <user> what you can also do is plot the precision recall curve , select an <unka> precision level ( e.g . 0.8 ) according to business considerations and select the model and threshold that maximizes the recall at that precision level . we currently do n't have a high level api to do this but the URL/http:/ <unka-./> <unka./_> function of <unka-> returns the <unka> for each point along the pr curve . </s>
<s> <user> once you have fitted your best model , you can compute its precision and recall on a held out test set to check that this is still fine , and further analyse that you do n't have strong <unka> in your precision recall metrics . for instance if you use your <unka> to build a <unka> systems for users , you can check that you get approximately similar performance for various ways to split your user base , e.g .: male vs female users , age groups , <unka> , very engaged users vs casual users ... </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> so given my feature is <unka> , should i just replace the levels with integers , or spread it across columns ? </s>
<s> <user> we have had discussions on this topic on the mailing list . either should work alright with trees . integers will require deeper trees to select for ( or against ) a single category . so the model parameters need to be tuned to whichever approach you take . </s>

<s> <user> if you truly want to dynamically " stop growing a cluster " based on custom criteria , i do n't think any of the <unka-> algorithms have an api for that . moreover , it would only apply to algorithms that incrementally grow clusters , e.g . hierarchical clustering . if your dataset is not huge and you do n't need to fit many different models , you could try implementing your own hierarchical clustering with simple python logic , and add your own constraints . it 's a fairly straightforward algorithm . </s>
<s> <user> as its <unka> , you dont lose a great deal by not stopping . you should just process the output of <unka_> to adhere to your criteria . </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> ah right .. so what is the right thing to do here ? </s>

<s> <user> i need to scale the data to use <unka> ( <unka> ) </s>
<s> <user> so i train on some set and the test on another </s>
<s> <user> how should i scale the test set ? </s>
<s> <user> if this method does n't guarantee it will be in the right range </s>
<s> <user> is there a technical reason why it needs to be in this range ? </s>
<s> <user> it will be in this range unless there are samples in the test set that are outside of the range of the training set </s>
<s> <user> hmm .. i do n't actually know .. it 's just that all the docs says you should scale everything to be in the range 0 to 1 </s>
<s> <user> yeah , then using <unka> in this way is exactly the right thing to do . </s>
<s> <user> ok thanks .. it occurred to me that you could just scale the test set independently too </s>
<s> <user> which would n't be " cheating " but would give you the guarantee </s>
<s> <user> but maybe that is wrong </s>
<s> <user> that will make it harder for the algorithm to generalize , because the meaning of the values in the training and test set will be different </s>
<s> <user> true and good point </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> there 's nothing <unka> specific about this , this is *the* objective for binary <unka> regression ( with penalty ) </s>
<s> <user> elements of statistical learning , chapter 4.4 </s>
<s> <user> URL/https:/ <unka./> <unka/~> </s>
<s> <user> the objective function for binary <unka> <unka> regression stems from the negative log likelihood of a linear <unka> the log odd ratio of the <unka> model . </s>
<s> <user> the linear <unka> ( <unka.> . x + b ) is for the log odd ratio <unka(> ( 1 - p )) instead of p directly , where p is the parameter of the <unka> function . </s>

<s> <user> hi , everyone i 'm new here so anything i need to know ? </s>
<s> <user> <unk#a@_> well , i guess i mean for <unka> regression . linear scaling <unka> should not have a direct impact for most models and methods . i think the linear scaling will just factor out of everything . of course , it might help with numerical stability if the target has extreme values . basically , intuition is that for regression methods , min <unka(> ) - y is same problem as min <unka(> ) - <unka\> * y but with a modified x . for example , you could just scale the weights of the last layer to get the different y . with sgd or whatever method you are using to solve , you could of course get different results with scaled y . this is not a proof of course ... just found this : URL/https:/ <unka./> <unk#a#-/> which is potentially a good <unka> of the details . </s>

<s> <user> hello everyone , i have a quick question regarding normalization ( <unka-> ) of output values . usually you are supposed to use normalization only on the training data set and then apply those stats to the validation and test set . but for instance , my prediction variable is a single percentage value ranging [ 0 , 100% ]. and i know for sure that in the " real world " regarding my problem statement , that i will get samples ranging form 60 - 100% . but my training set is to small and does not contain enough data points including all possible output values . so here comes my question : should i stay with my initial statement ( normalization only on training data ) or should i apply the maximum possible value of 100% for my output value to <unka()-> of the normalization step ? </s>

<s> <user> another silly idea was to squash my output value into the range [ 0,1 ] by applying <unk#a/> . does that make sense ? </s>
<s> <user> thats just chaning how you look at it , not really changing the properties of it </s>
<s> <user> just checking i understand your problem though . you are saying in your training set , you have min max output of something like .2 - .6 and so you are scaling that to <unk#-> . </s>
<s> <user> it depends on the problem you are trying to solve . you 'll have to decide if it is appropriate for your problem or not . </s>
<s> <user> what min max scaling does in that case is stretch the <unka> between .2 and .6 to a higher resolution , and then make <unka> outside .2 or .6 equal to each other </s>
<s> <user> if that makes sense to do will be application specific </s>

<s> <user> ok , yeah so any scaling that you do on your training data . you will want to apply those same normalization to the validation and test data </s>

<s> <user> <unka_> is the number of chunks produced . so <unk#a=_> means not to split the data at all , leave it in one chunk </s>

<s> <user> what is <unka> ? </s>
<s> <user> URL/https:/ URL/en.wikipedia.org/ <unka/_> </s>
<s> <user> <unka> is a linear way of reducing your dimensions to a few principal components . you can use neural networks for a non-linear approach for the same </s>
<s> <user> basically the last hidden layer of your neural network is a representation of your input in much the same way <unka> to principal components is </s>
<s> <user> the number of dimensions of this representation will be the number of <unka> in the last hidden layer </s>

<s> <user> <unk#a@> because gradient boosting tries to predict gradients which are always continuous targets , even in the case of <unka> . with a log loss ( as used in <unka> ) these gradients are <unka> to a <unka-> ratio , and are then passed through a <unka> function to become a probability between [ 0 , 1 ] </s>

<s> <user> hi all , what 's the reason why one should n't set other attributes during construction in <unka> <unka> apart from those in the <unka_`> signature ( see <unka> check : URL/https:/ URL/github.com/ <unk#a#)-./?_> if i understand it correctly , <unka`> calls the constructor and so all other attributes will also be re-set . </s>
<s> <user> <unka`> does n't call the constructor with the expected parameters . the parameters are set in <unka_`> . that means if setting some other attributes depends on some given attribute to <unka_`> , and that logic is not duplicated in <unka_`> , the constructor would be in an invalid state . putting those in <unka`> makes them all consistent . </s>
<s> <user> but there are ways where you can handle it with setting other parameters in <unka_`> , and the <unka> not going into an invalid state , if you know what you're doing , then you can ignore that test . </s>
<s> <user> thanks for the quick reply , yes , so , as long as there is no logic or interaction of attributes in <unka_`> , i can initialise other attributes in <unka_`> . we are developing a toolbox that extends <unka> to time series and currently have an <unka_`> attribute in our base <unka> which is initialised to <unka`> , any reason why this may be a bad idea ? </s>

<s> <user> <unka@_> i do n't think that using <unka> on chunks of the distance matrix would give you anything meaningful . i meant using <unka`> <unka> a sparse distance matrix , but then i 'm not sure if <unka`> actually supports sparse distance <unka> . you wo n't be able to compute a dense as for 100k samples that would be <unk#a/~> . generally <unka> does n't scale well with default options ( URL/https:/ <unka./> <unka./_> ) so i would suggest starting with a smaller dataset and progressively increase the number of samples to see how it scales . you may run into performance issues before memory ones . <unka@> i have n't looked at the code in detail , but internally it never uses <unka_`> on the full dataset . </s>

<s> <user> is dummy offensive ? </s>
<s> <user> i looked up why it 's offensive , and it seems most people think it is or may be offensive because of the way it 's use as a derogatory term to call somebody stupid or an idiot . now if we think of the people whom unfortunately are called often dumb or stupid by their friends or colleagues while many of them being very talented , we realize why the term may be a trigger for them . i personally do n't find it offensive in the context which is used in our library , but general rule of thumb is that if there are many reasonable people out there who thing something is offensive , then it 's offensive to them and i should avoid using the term , if that makes sense . </s>
<s> <user> could be wrong but my impression is that we mostly use the word dummy to denote " something designed to resemble and serve as a substitute for the real or usual thing ; a <unka> or sham " ( taken from google definition ). that might not be true in the case of <unka/> , where the name might come from the fact that these <unka> are over simplistic . though the previous definition could also hold for them . idk . changing their names will force lots of users to change their code though , so it 's not just going to be an internal change . as a side note we also have a bunch of " sanity checks " , deemed <unka-> by twitter , and i 'll admit i 'm quite puzzled by this one </s>

<s> <user> i have <unka/> : generally , for new algorithms , are there any reasons that <unka-> would prefer a <unka/> implementation over a <unka> implementation ? the only thing i can think of is if the efficiency gain for the <unka> version so minimal that it 's not worth the added complexity . but , are there any other reasons ? </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> yes , mostly readability and <unka> </s>
<s> <user> there is another potential reason in the future : using the <unka_> protocol and possibly <unka> 37 , pure numpy algorithm could directly be ported to gpu or distributed <unka> <unka> , while that 's not possible for <unka> implementations . </s>
<s> <user> ( this does n't say anything about how efficient that would be though ) </s>

<s> <user> <unka@> reviewing is always welcome and it 's a great way to learn ! the things i personally look for during a review are : - backward compatibility and consistency with the current library ecosystem . - test coverage . ideally we want tests to be fast as well . - docs : every new feature should be documented at least in the ug . big ones ideally come with a new example - code clarity and comments : you want your future self to be able to understand why something was done the way it was done in terms of where to find <unka> to review , we have a " waiting for <unka> " tag . also you can try filtering by <unka> which already have one approval : these might be easier to review . feel free to review old <unka> but note that there 's a chance these will never be addressed . </s>

<s> <user> i 'm not a big fan of heavy import statements , and having all those classes and functions as a top level import would make " import <unka> " very very heavy ( since it would load every <unka-> api immediately ). also , sometimes there may be conflicts between modules . other than that , i find the code more readable and understandable when imports are from the <unka-> instead of a top level import . </s>

<s> <user> it 's a pretty long list . some <unka-> specific ones are : </s>
<s> <user> ( was on mobile ) * allows <unka> of <unka> , allow <unka> and <unka> to work properly * allows you to use <unka-/> models to <unka> ( especially important since some <unka-> models have " extra " outputs ) * working <unka_> ( random state in <unka> is pretty complicated ) * adds <unka_`> and <unka_`> * your models can dynamically adjust the <unka> input/output shape to the data ( previously , that had to be hardcoded ) * support for <unka_`> in the same format as other <unka> <unka> ( including <unka"=_`> ). * a lot of compatibility improvements , stuff like implementing <unka_`> and <unka_`> * allows you to <unka-> parameters for <unka> and losses via [ routed <unka#(-./:]> ). </s>
<s> <user> some not <unka> specific advantages : * is actively maintained ( the tf team may [ <unk#a#(-./:]> ) the wrappers in tf ) * has actual [ <unka(./:]> ) </s>

<s> <user> > what is the use case they were created to cover ? to pipe an arbitrary number of <unka-> steps ( i.e . transformers ) with a final <unka> . e.g . <unka(_`> ), <unka()`> > in most of the examples , people groups processing " branches " by feature types ( <unka/> ) > is this the main use case pipelines were designed for ? not really . mapping different features to different transformers is the role of the <unka`> ( ct ). the ct is a <unka-> that will apply different <unka-> steps to specific features . these <unka-> steps can also be pipelines themselves . a ct is often used as the first step of a pipeline . </s>

<s> <user> is it possible to use <unka> instead of ct ? <unk`> <unka(=[> ( <unka'> , <unka(_> ), [ <unka'> ], <unka'=> <unk),> ( <unka'> , <unka(> )), # create additional feature ( <unka'> , <unka([> ... <unk),]> # transform the additional feature ]) <unk`> </s>
<s> <user> the issue here is that your <unka`> as a state depending of the strategy </s>
<s> <user> if you strategy is to replace by a constant </s>
<s> <user> then yes you can use a <unka`> and fill by a constant and make sure to return a <unka> </s>
<s> <user> however , if you " learn " ( e.g . mean , etc .) then <unka`> is not what you want because it is <unka> ( you will compute the mean on the train and test instead of using the train on the test ). </s>
<s> <user> otherwise you write a custom <unka> that recreate the <unka> when calling transform </s>
<s> <user> there is a lot of <unka> there and not an easy solution :) </s>

<s> <user> > yeah , why is that ? i feel like i 'm the only one who have such an issue :d i think that usually , people make the feature engineering even before to start a <unka-> pipeline </s>
<s> <user> basically you do your feature engineering in <unka> get your design matrix </s>
<s> <user> and then start processing . </s>
<s> <user> so when the <unka> is simple ( like the <unka_> example ), you can even integrate the <unka> within the first stage of the pipeline . </s>

<s> <user> how exactly does prediction work for gradient boosted trees ? in a random forest you just get a prob from every tree and average them i think . is this different for gradient boosted trees ? </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> in gradient boosting , one directly <unka> a loss function . for binary <unka> in <unka-> this is the log loss , much like <unka> regression . what the trees predict is the <unka-> ratio ( <unka(_> )) and it 's passed into a <unka> to get a probability ( <unka(_> )) </s>

<s> <user> hi ! i have a quick question about the capabilities of <unka-> 's pipeline ( also asked in the other channel ): currently my data looks like the following 0 20 1 23 2 25 3 29 4 24 ... where the index is a step in time , and the value is the value associated with that <unka> . i am <unka> it into 0 [ 20 , 23 , 25 ] [ 29 , 24 ] 1 [ 29 , 24 , 24 ] [ 23 , 22 ] 2 [ 23 , 22 , 26 ] [ 23 , 25 ] ... by running a sort of window function over it . the index then is sample number , the first array is the input features , and the second array is the target . if i input my data values as x into a pipeline , how to address the following : my custom transformer generates y from the input x , but the pipeline requires a y to begin with my custom transformer changes the length of x , which i think the pipeline also complains about . especially the latter is really important to me , as i want to be able to change the amount of features in x . other options for example would be : 0 [ 20 , 23 ] [ 25 , 29 ] 1 [ 25 , 29 ] [ 24 , 29 ] ... or even 0 [ 20 , 23 , 25 , 29 ] [ 24 , 29 ] 1 [ 24 , 29 , 24 , 24 ] [ 23 , 22 ] etc . is there a standard solution for this , or should i write a wrapper for this ? thanks in advance ! </s>
<s> <user> our pipelines are unfortunately no meant to change the number of samples or the target . so i guess this kind of <unka> will have to happen outside of the pipeline <unka-> ... </s>
<s> <user> is there a specific reason why that is prevented from being changed ? </s>
<s> <user> if the goal of the pipeline is to do parameter tuning for size of the <unka-> of the feature extraction preprocessor in a <unka/> ( for instance ), then i think it 's better to switch to a parameter tuner with a more flexible less opinionated api such as URL/https:/ <unka./> for instance . </s>
<s> <user> thank you ! </s>
<s> <user> > is there a specific reason why that is prevented from being changed ? our transformers where never meant to change y . this is an early design decision that is really hard to change now ( without breaking users code ). and changing the number of samples without changing y is meaningless . </s>
<s> <user> that 's a shame , because i can imagine <unka> different sampling strategies generating additional samples with differing noise levels would be a very useful thing to put in a pipeline so it can be <unka> . </s>
<s> <user> i 'll have a look at <unka> , thanks for your answers ! </s>
<s> <user> but 's really trick to get right , especially with the metrics . for instance when dealing with <unka> <unka> problems , you want to <unka> at training time but not at test validation prediction score time . <unka> learn has a custom pipeline and a custom api for <unka> transformers with the <unka_> method : URL/https:/ <unka-./> however this is not what you want for your use case : you want to perform the same transformation both at fit and predict time . it 's hard to express all those use cases in a simple and intuitive unified api that would not led to users to shoot themselves in the foot . and there the backward compat constraints to take into account which makes it really hard to make our api evolve in that regard . </s>

<s> <user> hello , i 'm using <unka.`> ( <unk#a-.=> ) to find nearest neighbors <unk`> <unka> = <unk#a(=_> , <unka'=> , <unka'=> , <unk#a=> , <unk#a-=_> ) <unka(._> u : <unk#a(.=> , -1 ), <unk#a=_> , <unka().=_> ), <unk#a=> ) <unk`> <unka_`> contains 5k rows and 77 columns ( from one hot encoding ) and the execution is around <unk#`> <unka`> ( <unka_> 's shape = > ( <unk#> , 77 )) is it normal to have this high execution ? any tips to improve the performance and <unka> this execution time ) ? thanks </s>
<s> <user> for each sample in <unka_`> you have to compute the distances with each sample in <unka_`> . so it is the reason why it is pretty costly . </s>
<s> <user> potential workaround : if you have some chance , you might want to create prototype by clustering your training data and compute <unka> to the <unka> instead of the original data </s>
<s> <user> another solution would be to use an <unka> nearest neighbors instead . something like annoy : URL/https:/ URL/github.com/ <unka/> </s>

<s> <user> i have two questions about <unka> . a ) when using early stopping do you end up with the " best model " according to the validation loss or the most recent one after it stops ? </s>
<s> <user> b ) is the validation set chosen by <unka> chosen at random and is it the same set for every iteration of the training ? </s>
<s> <user> maybe these should be asked on github as an issue ? </s>
<s> <user> a ) there 's no notion of best model . early stopping stops the training process if the score has n't improved by more than <unka`> in the last <unka_`> iterations . the score can be the loss or an arbitrary <unka> and it can be computed on the training set or on the validation set b ) yes and yes </s>
<s> <user> thank you . maybe best model <unka> be a good addition ? </s>
<s> <user> i 'm not sure what you mean by best model . there 's no notion of best model , only one model is built . if you mean " model with the lowest training loss " that 's basically the model at the last iteration , under the assumption that the training loss is always supposed to decrease ( unless your learning rate becomes too high ). if you mean " model with the lowest training loss that does n't make the validation loss go up " , that 's what early stopping is supposed to give you ( and it 's preferable to the former ) </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> let 's say the latter example you gave . the problem is that with early stopping you wait some number of iteration before deciding to stop . so the final iteration is not the best . that 's why <unka> for example has a <unka_> parameter . </s>
<s> <user> it is common in early stopping for the final <unka> loss to be higher than the loss a few <unka> before . how long you wait to see if the loss will start going down again is sometimes called " patience " . i think that 's what <unka> lightning calls it </s>
<s> <user> does using the fit function on a fitted model replace the fitted model , or update it ? </s>
<s> <user> i 'm trying to use a <unka> in a machine learning context , and i want to keep updating it with each test run i do </s>
<s> <user> obviously , i could in theory , take the model , and train it with the results of the particular test run , then merge the <unka> with the last model myself , but it would be better if i could avoid that </s>
<s> <user> <unka`> make a full training from scratch </s>
<s> <user> <unka_`> is doing an update </s>
<s> <user> <unka@> thank you . what kinds of models is <unka_> available for ? </s>

<s> <user> thanks ! i have a list of <unka> with their <unka> ( position , direction , energy and <unka> weight ). this variables are correlated . i want to fit that curves and later sample new <unka> . i want to know how <unka-> keep the correlation . i 'm sorry if it is a beginner question . and thanks again . </s>

<s> <user> does <unka> regression support <unka> <unka> as input for the x matrix ? URL/https:/ <unka-./> <unka#./_> does this then allow us to make use of the new attribute name : <unka_`> ? </s>
<s> <user> you can pass a <unka> </s>
<s> <user> currently <unka_`> be useless in <unka> and <unka> </s>
<s> <user> because we will convert into a numpy array to make the optimisation </s>
<s> <user> the idea for the moment is to propagate feature names in the <unka> steps </s>
<s> <user> such that you for instance know the name of the columns of the numpy array that will be passed to the <unka> regression ( and potentially build the <unka> ) </s>
<s> <user> the work that could be done for <unka> and <unka> is to make that the fitted attribute could use the feature names to decorate themselves </s>
<s> <user> but it can be still be easily done by getting the <unka_`> from the last <unka> stage and create for instance a <unka> series using the <unka> </s>
<s> <user> but for the moment we try that we can move the feature names in the <unka> </s>

<s> <user> hello , <unka> devs and contributors . i have a question regarding one of the examples left in pr <unk##> . <unka./_`> . i guess this one is left because is not as straightforward to accelerate . this example involves a <unka> regression using the saga algorithm and l1 penalty . in my attempt to optimize it , i found out that most of the running time is spent fetching the data instead of running the regression itself . the most i could do was 5% faster , which translates to 2 seconds difference . unfortunately , by reducing <unka_`> the running time is not <unka> decreased . another option i considered was to run <unka> with <unk#a.=`> and <unk#a=_`> , and <unk#a=_`> . unfortunately , ca n't get more than 5% . one of the tweaks i managed to do was in the plot itself , by running the <unka> outside the plot and using a list comprehension itself . overall it makes the plot faster . checking other <unka> , it seems that the acceleration obtained in this example is quite low . i am not sure even if this is an example that can be further improved considering the most expensive operation here is <unka_`> . for the same reason , not sure submitting a pr with such a low improvement is even a good idea . i appreciate your thoughts on it . maybe i 'm missing something relevant . thanks ! </s>
